etymology.culturalSignificance: In Roman mythology, Luna was the goddess of the moon, symbolizing purity and calmness. Her associations with the night sky have made the name Luna popular in various cultures.
etymology.historicalNotes: The name Luna originates from Latin, where it was used not only to refer to the moon but also as a deity. Over time, Luna transitioned from a common noun to a proper noun, becoming popular in literature and modern languages.

phonetics.rhythm: Luna has a flowing, light rhythm that carries a gentle quality, reminiscent of the moon's soft glow.
phonetics.phonosemantic: The sounds evoke feelings of tranquility and serenity, suitable for the moon's calming imagery.

morphology.grammaticalJourney: Initially a common noun in Latin, it evolved into a proper noun to refer to the divine representation of the moon, particularly in Roman culture and mythology.

famousBearers: Luna Luster (popular personality and social media influencer)
